'''Ray Fletcher Farquharson''' [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (4 August 1897 – 1 June 1965) was a Canadian doctor, university professor, and medical researcher. Born in [[Claude, Ontario]], he attended and taught at the [[University of Toronto]] for most of his life, and was trained and employed at [[Toronto General Hospital]]. With co-researcher [[Arthur Squires]], Farquharson was responsible for the discovery of the Farquharson phenomenon, an important principle of [[endocrinology]], which is that administering external hormones suppresses the natural production of that hormone.
He served in the [[First World War|First]] and [[Second World War]]s, earning appointment as a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] for his medical work during the latter. He chaired the Penicillin Committee of Canada and served as a medical consultant for the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]]. He was awarded the Queen's Coronation Medal in 1953 for his work for the Defence Review Board. Farquharson was also a charter member of the [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada]].
Farquharson was heavily involved in Canadian medical research and education. As a member of the [[National Research Council of Canada]], his "Farquharson Report" led to the establishment of the [[Medical Research Council of Canada]], of which he was the first president. He received numerous honorary degrees from Canadian universities, and served on the first Board of Governors of [[York University]]. He died in 1965, leaving a wife and two daughters. Farquharson was posthumously inducted into the [[Canadian Medical Hall of Fame]] in 1998.
==Early life and education== [[File:Rff-ww1.JPG|thumb|left|Farquharson in training during the First World War]] Farquharson was born in [[Claude, Ontario]] (a small town northwest of [[Toronto]]), on 4 August 1897 to Reverend William Farquharson, a [[Presbyterian]] minister, and Annie McDonald Coutts.<ref name=ww55>{{cite book|title=The Canadian Who's Who|chapter=Farquharson, Ray Fletcher|page=349|volume=7|date=1955–57|publisher=Trans-Canada Press}}</ref><ref name=proc>{{cite book|title=Proceedings of the Royal Society of Canada, series 4|volume=4|year=1966|author=Dauphinee, James|chapter=Ray Fletcher Farquharson|pages=83–89}}</ref> His brother Charles also became a doctor, while another brother, Robert, became the managing editor for ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' and was later an advisor at the Canadian Embassy to the United States.<ref name=proc/><ref name=globe2/> "Farquy", as he was nicknamed by friends,<ref name=globe2/> received his early education at [[Durham, Ontario|Durham]] and graduated from [[Harbord Collegiate Institute]] in Toronto.<ref name=proc/><ref name=mac/> He briefly attended the [[University of Toronto]]'s medical school before being drafted into the Canadian Army on 15 May 1918, serving in the [[Royal Regiment of Canadian Artillery|Canadian Field Artillery]] (67th Battery) as a [[gunner (rank)|gunner]]. He did not serve overseas, and was recalled from the military to complete his schooling, graduating in 1922.<ref name=proc/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdnmedhall.org/dr-ray-farquharson|accessdate=26 October 2011|title=Dr. Ray Farquharson|publisher=Canadian Medical Hall of Fame}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/databases/cef/001042-119.02-e.php?image_url=http://data2.archives.ca/cef/gpc003/319323a.gif&id_nbr=385075|accessdate=11 January 2011|publisher=Library and Archives Canada|title=Particulars of Recruit}}</ref> He underwent post-graduate study in various fields from 1922 until 1927<ref name=obit/> while serving as an intern and resident at [[Toronto General Hospital]] under [[Duncan Archibald Graham]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hill|first=Nicholas P|title=Fifty years in anaesthesia|journal=Canadian Journal of Anaesthesia|date=1 October 1995|volume=42|issue=10|pages=948–951|doi=10.1007/BF03011045|pmid=8706207}}</ref>
Farquharson was awarded research fellowships at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]], where he worked with [[Joseph Charles Aub]] and [[William Salter (doctor)|William Salter]],<ref name=proc/> and at [[Harvard University]]<ref name=obit/> before becoming an assistant professor at the University of Toronto.<ref name=bmj>{{cite journal|journal=British Medical Journal|title=Obituary notices|date=19 June 1965|page=1616|pmc=2167045|doi=10.1136/bmj.1.5450.1616|volume=1|issue=5450}}</ref> He published papers on the excretion of [[calcium]] in response to excessive acid in the body<ref>{{cite journal|last=Farquharson|first=Ray F|author2=Salter, William T |author3=Tibbetts, Dorothy M |author4= Aub, Joseph C |title=Studies of calcium and phosphorus metabolism|journal=Journal of Clinical Investigation|date=June 1931|volume=10|issue=2|pages=221–249|doi=10.1172/JCI100347|pmid=16693975 |pmc= 435745}}</ref> and "liver therapy" (the consumption of [[Liver (food)|liver]]) as a treatment for spinal cord degeneration.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Farquharson|first=Ray F|author2=Graham, Duncan |title=Liver therapy in the treatment of subacute combined degeneration of the cord|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|date=August 1930|volume=23|issue=2|pages=237–244|pmid=20317938 |pmc=382006}}</ref> In 1931 he married Christina Jane Fraser, with whom he had two daughters: Helen, who became a [[hematologist]], and Catherine Jane.<ref name=ww55/><ref name=hot/><ref name=ncbi/>
==Career== In addition to teaching at the University of Toronto, Farquharson established a private practice as a medical consultant, gaining a reputation as a "doctor's doctor" for his treatment of other physicians.<ref name=proc/> In 1934 he became the head of the therapeutics department at Toronto.<ref name=mc/> He continued to publish research findings on various topics, including [[anorexia nervosa]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Farquharson|first=RF|author2=Hyland, HH |title=Anorexia nervosa: a metabolic condition of psychologic origin|journal=Journal of the American Medical Association|year=1938|volume=111|issue=12|pages=1085–1092|doi=10.1001/jama.1938.02790380027007}}</ref> Farquharson was a charter member of the [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada]], which oversaw all Canadian postgraduate medical education; he served on its council from 1939 to 1943, and was the council's president from 1945 to 1947.<ref name=mc>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/Exhibitions/Medicentre/en/farq_print.htm|accessdate=27 October 2011|work=Medi-Centre|title=Dr. Ray Farquharson|publisher=Virtual Museum of Canada}}</ref> Prior to enlisting in the Second World War, he gave testimony as an expert medical witness in [[court martial]] trials.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Court-martial hears witness in hospital|newspaper=Globe and Mail|date=14 April 1943|url=http://collections.civilisations.ca/warclip/objects/common/webmedia.php?irn=5028999}}</ref>
[[File:Rff-ww2.JPG|thumb|Ray Fletcher Farquharson during the Second World War]] On 25 August 1943, Farquharson enlisted in the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] (RCAF) and was assigned to No. 1 Air Command, based in [[Trenton, Ontario]]. He was posted to the United Kingdom in 1944 and briefly returned to No. 1 Air Command before being released from service on 22 November 1945 with the rank of [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]].<ref name=ncbi>{{cite journal|author=Detweiler, Herbert K|title=Ray Fletcher Farquharson|year=1966|volume=77|pages=l–li|journal=Transactions of the American Clinical and Climatological Association|pmid=5328601|pmc=2441115}}</ref> During the war, he chaired the Penicillin Committee of Canada, which regulated the distribution of [[penicillin]] (an antibiotic that largely replaced the [[Sulfonamide (medicine)|sulfonamide]] used earlier in the war)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.niu.edu/2001/iht810139.html|title=Penicillin|author1=Mailer, John S Jr |author2=Mason, Barbara |publisher=Illinois Periodicals Online|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> to the armed forces,<ref>{{Harvnb|Horlick|2007|p=29}}</ref> and was a consultant to the RCAF's Director of Medical Services.<ref name=obit/> He was also consulted on medical matters by both the other branches of the Canadian armed forces and by various [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] medical groups.<ref name=mbe/> He supervised medical experiments involving penicillin therapy conducted in Ontario hospitals in 1943–44,<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Globe and Mail|author=Tupper, Janet|title='Terrifying magnitude' of venereal diseases put before conference|date=7 December 1943|page=7}}</ref> and was temporarily appointed Director of Medicine at Christie St. Veteran's Hospital in Toronto.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Globe and Mail|title=Appoint two directors at Christie St. Hospital|date=26 September 1945|page=4}}</ref> After [[V-E Day]], he travelled to Belgium to supervise the administration of penicillin therapy, and later became involved in the care and treatment of war veterans. For his service in the war, Farquharson was appointed a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] in January 1946.<ref name=mbe>{{cite web|url=http://airforce.ca/uploads/airforce/2009/07/ALPHA-FA.html|accessdate=30 October 2011|publisher=Air Force Association of Canada|title=Farquharson, W/C Ray Fletcher}}</ref> His brother Charles also served in both world wars.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Obituaries|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|volume=104|issue=12|page=1074|date=19 June 1971|pmc=1931029}}</ref>
Farquharson was the director of medicine for Toronto veterans' hospitals from 1945 to 1947, and at the same time served as president of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada.<ref name=obit/> In 1947 he was appointed to the Sir John and Lady Eaton Professor of Medicine chair at the University of Toronto.<ref name=mc/> From 1947 until his retirement in 1960, he was the Physician-in-Chief of the Toronto General Hospital. His well-known patients included Canadian politician [[George A. Drew]], who he advised to resign as head of the [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada]] and [[Leader of the Opposition (Canada)|Leader of the Opposition]] following a near-fatal attack of [[meningitis]];<ref>{{Harvnb|Creighton|1976|p=286}}</ref> Drew did so, and was succeeded as party leader by [[John Diefenbaker]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Canada]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Bliss|2004|p=188}}</ref> Farquharson established clinical teaching programs at Women's College Hospital and [[Sunnybrook Hospital]], and expanded those already in place at St. Michael's and Toronto Western. He also appointed the first full-time clinical investigators to the Toronto medical school faculty and increased total faculty numbers from 40 to over 100.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deptmedicine.utoronto.ca/About_Us/History.htm|accessdate=30 October 2011|publisher=University of Toronto|title=Ray F. Farquharson|year=2007}}</ref> He became a Fellow of the [[American College of Physicians]] in 1947 and of the [[Royal College of Physicians]] in 1950.<ref name=ww55/> He was appointed a member of the Bacteriological Warfare Review Committee, established in 1950 by the [[Defence Research Board]] (of which he was a member from 1949 to 1952) and chaired by Dr. [[Charles Herbert Best|Charles Best]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Best|2003|p=292}}</ref> For his service to the nation, he was awarded the [[Queen's Coronation Medal]] in 1953.<ref name=mbe/>
Through his research in [[endocrinology]] with colleague Arthur Squires,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Johnston|first=Macallister W|author2= Squires, AH|author3=Farquharson, RF|date=November 1951|title= The effect of prolonged administration of thyroid|journal= Annals of Internal Medicine|volume=35|issue=5|pages=1008–1022|pmid=14885883|doi=10.7326/0003-4819-35-5-1008}}</ref> Farquharson discovered what became known as the "Farquharson Phenomenon": that the introduction of continuous [[exogenous]] [[Hormone#Pharmacology|hormone doses]] suppresses the natural production of that hormone in the patient and causes temporary atrophy in the producing organ.<ref name=proc/><ref name=mac/> This phenomenon became one of the basic principles of endocrinology and a key factor in the etiology of hormonal abnormalities.<ref name=proc/><ref name=hot>{{cite video|title=Hot docs: heroes of Canadian medicine|medium=CD|publisher=Canadian Medical Hall of Fame|date=2000}}</ref> Farquharson also made significant contributions related to [[anemia]] and [[secondary metabolism|pigment metabolism]].<ref name=proc/><ref name=obit/> He was the first Canadian doctor to publicize [[Sheehan's syndrome]], and the first North American to report on [[Simmond's disease]].<ref name=bmj/><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Modern Medicine|title=Contemporaries|pages=85–86|date=11 November 1963|volume=31|issue=23|editor=Page, Irvine}}</ref> As an educator and researcher, he was an early promoter of laboratory testing in the evaluation of illness; he was known for advocating both this and awareness of potential psychological issues in patients.<ref name=proc/>
Farquharson became a member of the [[National Research Council of Canada]] in 1951,<ref name=hot/> and in 1957 was named the director of the Division of Medical Research.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society|title=James Bertram Collip, 1892–1965|volume=19|date=December 1973|author1=Barr, ML |author2=Rossiter, RJ |pmid=11615724|pages=235–267 [250]|doi=10.1098/rsbm.1973.0009}}</ref> In 1958, he chaired a [[Privy Council]] Committee tasked with producing a report on the state of medical research in Canada; this charge was in response to a 1957 report by the Association of Canadian Medical Colleges to the Prime Minister, which suggested that medical research in Canada was underfunded.<ref name=proc/> While researching his report, he visited the Soviet Union in 1959 as part of a contingent representing the Research Council; he remarked on the country's apparent emphasis on scientific research, and invited Soviet scientists to visit Canada.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Globe and Mail|title=Canadians see USSR stressing research|date=19 November 1959|page=8}}</ref> Farquharson concluded that existing government support for research in Canada failed to specifically address medical research as an independent discipline and was financially insufficient.<ref name=mac>{{cite book|chapter=Farquharson, Ray Fletcher|title=MacMillan Dictionary of Canadian Biography|publisher=MacMillan|year=1978|edition=4th|editor1=Wallace, W. Stewart |editor2=McKay, WA |page=252}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title= Report on the meeting of the Association of Canadian Medical Colleges: The Medical Research Council of Canada | journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal | date=December 1960 | volume=83 | issue=25 | pages=1331–1334 | pmc=1939026 }}</ref> His "Farquharson Report" led to the formation of the [[Medical Research Council of Canada]] in 1960, over which he presided until his death.<ref name=mc/> As president, Farquharson advocated for progressive medical education taught by practicing physicians<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|title=The leaven of science|date=9 April 1966|volume=94|issue=15|pmc=1935393|pmid=20328536|pages=812–813}}</ref> and for continuing education via research for doctors.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Farquharson|first=Ray F|title=Value of participation in research in continuing education of practicing doctors|journal=Journal of the American Medical Association|date=5 September 1959|volume=171|issue=1|pages=26–29|doi=10.1001/jama.1959.03010190028008 |pmid=13821614}}</ref> He was also able to increase the organization's budget for awards and grants from [[C$]]4 million in 1963 to $9 million by 1965.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dsp-psd.pwgsc.gc.ca/Collection/MR21-19-2000E.pdf|title=Celebrating the Medical Research Council of Canada|page=15|publisher=Medical Research Council of Canada|accessdate=30 October 2011}}</ref>
Farquharson became the Regent of the American College of Physicians in 1958 after having spent three years as the organization's Ontario representative. He joined the first Board of Governors of [[York University]] in 1959, and was a member of the University of Toronto Senate in the same year.<ref name=proc/><ref name=obit>{{cite journal|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|title=Obituaries|date=17 July 1965|volume=93|issue=3|page=133|pmc=1928688}}</ref> He was named a Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada in 1960.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Canadian Who's Who|year=1961–63|volume=9|page=343|publisher=Trans-Canada Press|chapter=Farquharson, Ray Fletcher}}</ref> He was also a member of a number of medical organizations in both Canada and the US,<ref>{{cite book|title=The Canadian Who's Who|publisher=Trans-Canada Press|date=1958–60|volume=8|page=350|chapter=Farquharson, Ray Fletcher}}</ref> and chairman or board member for some 20 medical research groups.<ref name=proc/>
==Retirement and legacy== In 1960, having reached the University of Toronto's compulsory retirement age,<ref name=proc/> Farquharson left the university and the hospital. In recognition of his work for Toronto General Hospital, the twelve-bed Clinical Investigation Unit was named after him in 1961, and the Farquharson Foundation was established to support research conducted by the university's teaching hospitals.<ref name=obit/><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Globe and Mail|title=Hospital unit honors Dr. Farquharson; foundation will support research|author=Hollobon, Joan|page=3|date=14 December 1961}}</ref> Also in 1961, Farquharson visited India, later remarking on the societal respect for doctors there.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Globe and Mail|title=MD advises patients to clarify symptoms|date=28 February 1961|page=23}}</ref> He also continued to advocate for support for universities.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Globe and Mail|title=Plan to use funds to assist research|date=23 June 1961|page=9}}</ref>
Farquharson won the [[Heart and Stroke Foundation of Canada|National Heart Foundation]]'s Award of Merit in 1960,<ref name=proc/> followed by the [[Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association of Canada]] Health Research Foundation's Medal of Honour in 1964 "for his clinical assessment of antibiotics [and] service as a leading medical educator", becoming one of only 18 people to ever receive this award.<ref>{{Harvnb|Best|2003|p=395}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.canadapharma.org/en/difference/foundation/honour.aspx|publisher=Canada's Research-Based Pharmaceutical Companies|accessdate=30 October 2011|title=Medal of Honour}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|title=Outstanding research earns two MDs pharmaceutical-industry honour|date=15 November 1994|volume=151|issue=10|author=Rafuse, J|pmc=1337420 |pmid=7954143|pages=1479–1481 [1481] }}</ref> He was featured on the cover of ''[[Modern Medicine]]'' in November 1963.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ihm.nlm.nih.gov/luna/servlet/detail/NLMNLM~1~1~101414694~193321:Dr--Ray-F--Farquharson|title=Images from the history of medicine|publisher=US National Library of Medicine|accessdate=30 October 2011}}</ref> Farquharson was granted honorary degrees by a number of Canadian universities:<ref name=bmj/> the [[University of British Columbia]] in 1949,<ref name=proc/> the [[University of Saskatchewan]] in 1957,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usask.ca/archives/history/hondegrees.php?id=102&view=detail&keyword=&campuses=|publisher=University of Saskatchewan|accessdate=30 October 2011|title=Honorary degree recipients}}</ref> [[Laval University]] in 1959, [[Queen's University]] in 1960,<ref name=proc/> the [[University of Alberta]] in 1960,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ualbertacentennial.ca/achievements/degrees/1960.html|title=Honorary Degree Recipients (1960s)|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=30 October 2011}}</ref> the University of Toronto in 1962, and the [[University of Montreal]] in 1965.<ref name=proc/> He was named an honorary member of the Ontario Medical Association.<ref name=globe2/> He was also appointed a Knight of the Military and Hospitaller Order of St Lazarus of Jerusalem and an Honorary Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Medicine]] in [[London]].<ref name=proc/><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of Medicine|title=Special lectures and awards|volume=58|issue=7|date=July 1965|pmc=1898620|pages=559–560}}</ref>
[[File:Farquharson Life Sciences Building York University.jpg|thumb|left|Farquharson Life Sciences Building, [[York University]], Toronto]] Farquharson died on 1 June 1965 at Ottawa Civic Hospital at age 68 after suffering a [[heart attack]].<ref name=globe2>{{Cite news|newspaper=Globe and Mail|title=Physician was head of Medical Council|page=41|date=2 June 1965}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Best|2003|p=401}}</ref> He had been in [[Ottawa]] to attend a meeting of the Medical Research Council.<ref name=proc/> The University of Toronto held a memorial service commemorating his contributions to the school and the medical community.<ref name=yu>{{cite web|publisher=York University|title=1965|url=http://www.library.yorku.ca/ccm/ArchivesSpecialCollections/FindingAids/YorkChronology/1965.htm|accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref>
The Farquharson Life Sciences Building, the first science building at York University, was renamed in honour of Farquharson.<ref name=yu/> A biography of Farquharson was planned, but was never completed.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|title=Biography of Dr. Ray Farquharson planned|author=Dauphinee, James A|date=20 February 1971|volume=104|page=337|issue=4|pmc=1930861 |pmid=20311756 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.library.utoronto.ca/utarms/findingaids/B1985-0006fa.pdf|accessdate=30 October 2011|publisher=University of Toronto Archives|title=James Arnold Dauphinee|author=Wells, Garron|date=April 2010|page=10}}</ref> The Ray F. Farquharson Memorial Lecture was established in his memory; the first such lecture was delivered by [[John Eager Howard]] of [[Johns Hopkins University]] in 1968 on the topic of [[calcium metabolism]].<ref>{{Cite news|newspaper=Globe and Mail|date=21 February 1968|page=10|title=Delicate balance kept by calcium in body}}</ref> He was posthumously inducted into the [[Canadian Medical Hall of Fame]] in 1998 alongside such notable figures as [[Tommy Douglas]], [[Norman Bethune]] and [[Roberta Bondar]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|page=211|volume=159|issue=3|date=11 August 1998|title='Father of Medicare' among 11 inductees into Medical Hall of Fame|author=Wharry, Steven|pmc=1229536}}</ref><ref>{{cite hansard|jurisdiction=Canada|house=Senate|date=12 May 1998|speaker=Keon, Wilbert J|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/Content/Sen/Chamber/361/Debates/060db_1998-05-12-e.htm#0.2.X57BJ2.YURZ7K.3RPQ0H.MB2|title=Canadian Medical Hall of Fame}}</ref>
Farquharson was credited by Professor William Goldberg of [[McMaster University]] with "attack[ing] racism as part of [his] clinical teaching" because he suggested patient race should only be mentioned if relevant to their diagnosis;<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|author=Goldberg, William M|year=1998|volume=159|issue=8|title=Lessons about racism|pages=917–918|pmid=9834709 |pmc=1229725}}</ref> he is also credited with combating [[anti-Semitism]].<ref>{{cite web|work=Jewish Independent|title=Anti-Semitism in the hospitals|author=Johnson, Pat|date=18 January 2002|url=http://www.jewishindependent.ca/archives/Jan02/archives02jan18-04.html|accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref> He is considered one of the "Fathers of Canadian Medicine" in both medical research and education.<ref name=obit/> According to one memorial, "no Canadian since Sir [[William Osler]] has left as great an imprint upon the practice of Medicine".<ref name=ncbi/>
